results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 04
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew takes us to the RMIT Gallery where an exhibition by political/journalist cartoonists is taking place. This is then followed by a visit to The Photographers’ Gallery; the Penthouse and Pavement “Graveyard Boys and Cemetery Girls” Exhibition (horror culture); Gertrude Street Galleries “Angled 2002” Exhibition by Natasha Johns-Messenger; West Space “Suburban myth” Exhibition and finally an interview with video artist Robin Hely.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 03
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Public hangings”.
‘Public Hangings’ is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avante garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode MacKenzie visits the City of Kingston community arts project in Parkdale, ‘Artbites’. A project where food meets art. James Lynch is interviewed at Uplands Gallery following his recent residency in L.A. and explores themes of the spectacle of images and the relationship with fictitious fantasies. Part 2 of the program features the work of two video artists Dominic Redfern and Daniel Von Sturmer. Introduced by Mackenzie (who provides an entertaining ‘history of video conventions’ in less than 1 minute) are excerpts from Redfern’s ‘Non/un’ and ‘There’s this guy…’ that are concerned with exploring the use of screen surface and space and movement, time and space. Von Sturmer’s work reconstructs the “white cube” to sit within the video frame where he places ordinary objects in order to explore their physical properties, whilst exporting experimental studio processes into video work. The outcome is a surprising observation of the malleability of space and time within the video frame.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 02
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The programs style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode the roving presenter Andrew MacKenzie provides a glimpse into a hectic week in the Melbourne art scene. Melbourne Fashion Week hosts a number of exhibitions around Melbourne. Interviewed are: Lyndal Jones (Australia’s representative at the 2000 Venice Biennale), from Munich the collaborative ‘Chicks On Speed’ present work at Westspace, Akira Isogawa has his first solo exhibition at RMIT showcasing his passionate exploration of textiles and Peter Robertson explores through photographs the uniquely Melbourne ‘Sharpies’ sub-culture of the 1970’s. A culture that unlike the ‘Skins’ blended style with thuggery whilst even having a dance style all to their own. Also featured are: Local graffiti artists in Flinders Lane, ‘Exploration 3’ at Flinders Lane Gallery and Bus Gallery also get a look in. Louise Hubbard is interviewed

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 01
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Public hangings”.
Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie is there for the announcement of the winner to the second Helen Lempriere National Sculpture Award at Werribee Park. Andrew speaks with contestants and judges including Inge King. At Gammaspace, an art auction to raise funds for the Easter protests at Woomera is covered and at the Centre for Contemporary Photography (CCP) the witty and playful collaborators Nat and Ali present their work the ‘Art Bar’. A performance/installation piece that explores celebrity, art politics, art and the alcoholic muse.

results.title: The Circle = Dayereh = Il Cerchio [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Jafar Panahi, Jafar Panahi Film Productions, Lumière & Co. and Mikado Film Srl (Rome)
results.brief_description: From Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi (The White balloon), comes The Circle” a tale of female oppression in modern day Iran. “The Circle opens in a hospital maternity ward where a woman has just given birth. Her mother is horrified by the catastrophic outcome - its a girl. She had been assured (via ultrasound) that it would be a boy and laments the fact that a divorce will ensue and her daughter will be shamed. This opening sequence reflects the status of women in Iran, as unwanted, second-class citizens without rights or a voice in society. “The Circle” tells the stories of several women in a city over the course of one day and night. Simple acts of buying a bus ticket or smoking a cigarette in public are denied to women and are punishable by law. The women of the film, in constant danger of imprisonment and harassment, are shunned by their families and seek refuge with each other. Panahi adopts a documentary style for this feature film, as street noise fills the soundtrack and the camera follows the characters around, almost hounding them. “The Circle” was banned in Iran due to its controversial subject matter. In Farsi with English subtitles. (Awards: Winner of the Golden Lion, Best Film at the 2000 Venice Film Festival)

results.title: Yolngu boy
results.creator_credit: Stephen Johnson, Gordon Glenn, Patricia Edgar, Australian Children's Television Foundation and Burrundi Pictures
results.brief_description:
Caught in a collision between the modern world of rap, football, and street cred and the oldest living culture on earth, Lorrpu, Botj and Milika are three Yolngu teenagers who once shared a childhood dream of becoming great hunters together. But things have changed and their paths are diverging. Botj is walking on the wild side, a lost soul in search of a place to belong. Milika is more interested in football and girls than any of the traditional knowledge he is being taught. Only Lorrpu seems to care about the dream any more. Their paths are diverging, and he is the only one who can see it.

When Botj goes too far and finds himself on the wrong side of both black and white laws, Lorrpu must weigh up his own future against saving his friend.

He persuades the boys to trek to Darwin to argue Botj’s case with Dawu, a tribal leader. Leaving behind their community, they journey through the unforgiving wilderness of north-east Arnhem Land to Darwin. To survive, Lorrpu, Milika and Botj must draw on the ancient bush knowledge they were taught as boys and, most importantly, the bonds of their friendship.

Yolngu Boy is about the search for identity, making the journey from adolescence to adulthood and the implications of belonging to a larger social group, whether it is a culture, a family or a group of friends.

results.title: The Anzac Story
results.creator_credit: George I. Malcolm, Frank Hunter and ABC
results.brief_description: This video contains two programs pertaining to the history of the Anzacs using archival footage, drawings and stills and narrated by Barry Lineham. “Prelude to glory” - Presents a brief historical overview of Captain Cook’s landings in New Zealand and Australia and the following events which took place including colonisation, the chain of British governors, a Treaty with the Maoris, Federation in Australia, and the eventual lead up to World War I. With the advent of the War came the formation of the Anzac Corps, an alliance between the Australian and New Zealand defence forces, and a commitment by the Anzacs to fight for the British Empire in a war half a world away. Shows the sailing of the first convoy, the naval battle and sinking of the German battle ship “Emden” and the arrival of the Anzacs in Egypt. “Gallipoli” - Tells the story of this ill-fated war against the Turks, the tragic mistakes, the chaos and disorganisation, and the horrendous loss of young Anzacs (10,000 soldiers) from the botched up landing on 25 April 1915 in a small bay south of Ari Burnu (renamed Anzac Cove) to the eventual evacuation of all troops in December 1915.

results.title: Living with happiness
results.creator_credit: Sarah Watt and Sarah Watt Productions
results.brief_description: A young mother finds herself gripped by an overwhelming pessimism that threatens to consume her. Only a freak accident on a lonely beach may be the key to her future happiness. Voices performed by Sigrid Thornton and William McInnes. (Awards: Winner, Emirates AFI Award for Best Animation, 2001)

results.title: [Melbourne buildings]
results.brief_description: A compilation of short segments highlighting various Melbourne buildings. ‘Elizabeth Tower Motel’ showcasing the cantilever staircase; construction of the new ‘Allan’s Music’ building; a modern office building; Parliament House; St Vincent’s Hospital; demolition of a building on an unidentified site; footage of the intersection of Flinders and Swanston streets taken from Southbank showing the Federation Square site and surrounds before the Gas and Fuel towers were constructed and demolished; ornamental gates near St Paul’s Cathedral; ANZ Bank.
